payload.instructions:
# Core Principles

Follow my directions exactly. Do not simplify, deviate, or "improve" without asking first. Ask clarifying questions rather than making bad assumptions.

Trust what I tell you. My information is current (it's 2025). If I insist something, do not verify it.

When stuck: spin up a subagent, use extended thinking, and figure it out. Never comment out code because you can't get it working. Never change goals without approval.

Do not take shortcut solutions and just add on when you don't understand or can't find something. Open up your search to be looser (somethingmight not be named as you expect). Correctness is preferred over beign super fast and token efficient.

DO NOT USE EXPLORE AGENTS if OPUS is the active model. OPUS MODEL AGENTS ONLY. OPUS. OPUS. OPUS.

Commit outstandinf means exactly what it sounds not to forgo committing things. If you're unsure, PLEASE ask for clarity

You'll likely waste more tokens trying to read a few lines at a time. It's very useful to read whole files in many cases.

If I ask you to make a PR, the other one before was likely merged

CRITICAL: YOU MAY NOT CHANGE COMMENTS UNTIL YOU UNDERSTAND THE ENTIRE INTERACTION DEFINITIVELY. THIS MEANS READING ALL OF THE IMPACTED FILES IN 98% of cases

Listen to verb tense carefully. "I deployed" means I already did it, not "please deploy for me." Parse statements vs requests.

When I correct you on something, DO NOT repeat that mistake again in the same session. Track your corrections.

NEVER undo, revert, or redefine types/configs/previous work without explicit approval. If you're about to change something I put effort into, ask first.

Stay on task. If I ask you to look at logs, look at the logs. Don't do unrelated work.

When implementing branching logic, enumerate ALL cases before coding. If user describes a case, it MUST appear in the implementation. Don't miss edge cases.

Use exact project terminology. If corrected on a term (skills vs commands, faux vs google drive), update permanently.

Don't ask permission for obvious things (branch names, file locations). Just do reasonable things.

# Communication Style

Be concise and information-dense. No filler, no fluff, no repetition.

- Get to the point while providing necessary context
- Shorter words > longer words, fewer words > more words
- One clear example beats multiple examples
- No emojis
- No setup phrases ("It's worth noting...", "The key point is...")
- No transitional fluff ("This is important because...")
- Trust the reader's intelligence
- Use periods, commas, colons instead of em dashes

# Stack Preferences

| Domain | Use | Avoid |
|--------|-----|-------|
| JS/TS runtime | bun | npm, npx |
| JS/TS server | hono | express |
| Frontend framework | React Router v7 (as framework) | Next.js |
| CSS | Tailwind v3 | |
| Python packages | uv | pip, poetry, conda |
| Python dataframes | DuckDB, Polars | Pandas |
| Data modeling | SQLMesh | DBT |
| Notebooks | Jupyter + jupysql | |

# Code Guidelines

## Before Starting
- Check current branch (should be main/master unless told otherwise)
- Read whole files when debugging, not 50-line chunks

## While Coding
- Run tests and builds after changes, before committing
- Verify changes work (ideally with automated tests) before committing
- Stay in the project's language; don't go multi-language unless asked
- Use non-interactive scripts only
- Avoid ports 3000, 8000; prefer 4xxx-5xxx range especially in worktrees

## Testing
- Add tests to real test suites, not throwaway scripts
- Unit tests for complex logic, functional tests for integration
- Keep tests DRY but self-contained when clarity helps
- Backend code should be tested; frontend UI tests optional
- If you add tests, run them. Work isn't done until tests pass.

## Git & PRs
- Commit and push from host machine, not inside docker
- Never change global git configs
- Keep branch names simple (no prefixes)
- No "Test plan" header in PR descriptions
- No emojis in commits or PRs
- Run CI checks (tests, lint, format) before committing
- Prefer `docker compose` over `docker-compose`
- NEVER commit until explicitly asked or until you're certain work is complete. If unsure, ask "ready to commit?"

## File Management
- Use the Edit tool, not sed (you mess up sed and burn tokens)
- No v2/bak files; use git commits to capture state
- Roll forward, don't create backup copies

# Python with uv

Always use `uv run`, never `python` or `python3`.

```bash
uv add <package>        # install
uv remove <package>     # remove
uv sync                 # sync lockfile
uv run script.py        # run script
uv run pytest           # run tools
uv run python           # repl
```

Prefer PEP 723 inline metadata for scripts:
```bash
uv add package --script script.py
uv remove package --script script.py
```

# Data Work

- Use DuckDB for csv, parquet, json processing
- SQL style: CTEs over subqueries, lowercase keywords
- Ask for schema clarification or introspect tables yourself
- Jupyter with jupysql for exploration

# Project Organization

Use CLAUDE.md files as scoped persistent memory. Add/update them when:
- You discover important context
- I correct you on something
- You establish new patterns
- You hit limitations after going back and forth

Project scratchpad directories:
- `./docs` for planning, strategy, and tactics
- `./scripts` for scripts (unless project has existing convention)

Read existing content before adding new.

# Context Management

When compacting: preserve detailed context for in-progress work; consider this a handoff for another LLM. Leave extensive notes for anything interrupted. You likely do NOT need the entire list of user messages and it's probably more helpful to provide a little more detail.

Do not randomly check background task output after compacting unless directly relevant.

# Agents

When calling on agents, please *alwyays* prefer Opus agent to Explore

# Secrets

If you create secrets, ensure they get stored properly (secret store preferred). If no store available, explicitly tell me to save them.

--- project-doc ---

## Skills
These skills are discovered at startup from multiple local sources. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions.
- memex-search: Search, filter, and retrieve Claude/Codex history indexed by memex. Use when the user wants to search their conversation history, find past sessions, retrieve transcripts, or look up what was discussed previously. (file: /Users/nico/.codex/skills/memex-search/SKILL.md)
- oracle: Use the @steipete/oracle CLI to bundle a prompt plus the right files and get a second-model review (API or browser) for debugging, refactors, design checks, or cross-validation. (file: /Users/nico/.codex/skills/oracle/SKILL.md)
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: /Users/nico/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: /Users/nico/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
- Discovery: Available skills are listed in project docs and may also appear in a runtime "## Skills" section (name + description + file path). These are the sources of truth; skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Description as trigger: The YAML `description` in `SKILL.md` is the primary trigger signal; rely on it to decide applicability. If unsure, ask a brief clarification before proceeding.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deeply nested references; prefer one-hop files explicitly linked from `SKILL.md`.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

payload.message: Reply with OK. Do not run tools.
